This looks very interesting, St=E9phane.  I think we could use this on the =
project I'm working on right now.  We'll give it a try when we have time.  =
Thanks for sharing it.
 
 
Todd.


________________________________

	From:=
 St=E9phane TRAUMAT [mailto:stephane.traumat@...] 
	Sent: Thursday, F=
ebruary 17, 2005 2:56 PM
	To: junit@yahoogroups.com
	Subject: [junit] JUnit=
Scenario 0.1 released
	
	
	
	Hi 
	
	We just released a new product under LG=
PL.. maybe it could interest you..
	
	Description: JunitScenario is an auto=
mation framework on top of JUnit
	to perform functional tests and stressing=
 tests.
	JUnitScenario is a tool to simulate real life usage of application=
s.
	It allows you to describe scenarios that are composed of unit tests
	ca=
lls and simulate several users following those scenarios.
	
	For example, t=
his scenario.xml file defines the cashier scenario:
	
	<scenario name=3D"ca=
shier" users=3D"20" loops=3D"500">
	  <task JUnitClass=3D"org.mybank.MyFirs=
tTest"
	JUnitMethod=3D"testCreateAccount" wait=3D"10"/>
	  <task JUnitClass=
=3D"org.mybank.MyFirstTest"
	JUnitMethod=3D"testDipositMoney" wait=3D"10"/>=

	  <task JUnitClass=3D"org.mybank.MyFirstTest"
	JUnitMethod=3D"testWithdra=
wMoney" wait=3D"50"/>
	</scenario>
	
	The goal is to have a very easy way t=
o use your unit tests to test
	your application scability.
	
	This document=
 describes how to setup the example:
	http://junitscenario.sourceforge.net/=
?action=3Dexample
	
	Visit JUnitScenario homepage at http://junitscenario.s=
ourceforge.net/
	
	This release is just a first shot; we are planning to re=
factor it,
	develop an eclipse plug-in to easily build scenarios, store tes=
ts in a
	database for statistics.
	
	--
	St=E9phane TRAUMAT
	scub.net
